elements.2211.03241_ad57fb098a6c984c853e4691c4237: Neural network-based approaches for solving partial differential equations (PDEs) have recently received special attention
elements.2211.03241_0491c9f91cd4266a3086892128a60: However, the large majority of neural PDE solvers only apply to rectilinear domains, and do not systematically address the imposition of Dirichlet/Neumann boundary conditions over irregular domain boundaries
elements.2211.03241_2632b4e314a32d2fa930b674fa420: In this paper, we present a framework to neurally solve partial differential equations over domains with irregularly shaped (non-rectilinear) geometric boundaries
elements.2211.03241_8dd771cb7dd3b44c9fa60a53fdbc1: Our network takes in the shape of the domain as an input (represented using an unstructured point cloud, or any other parametric representation such as Non-Uniform Rational B-Splines) and is able to generalize to novel (unseen) irregular domains; the key technical ingredient to realizing this model is a novel approach for identifying the interior and exterior of the computational grid in a differentiable manner
elements.2211.03241_b56da4554e732a2e99cf0e5ab0e35: We also perform a careful error analysis which reveals theoretical insights into several sources of error incurred in the model-building process
elements.2211.03241_996c7d3e7eaa90974b88af1b7b7a7: Finally, we showcase a wide variety of applications, along with favorable comparisons with ground truth solutions.
elements.2211.03241_9a5080e14c6e1c7400403bc601c55: Most physical phenomena are modeled using a set of governing partial differential equations (PDEs)
elements.2211.03241_37b7f38b1d67bccb539857a33ee0f: finite difference (FDM), finite element (FEM), and spectral methods
elements.2211.03241_5b1aa58c9853218c3c650b26853b4: for solving PDEs discretize the physical domain (into cells, elements, etc.) and
elements.2211.03241_89489529da469b79fb09238f208ce: the solution over this discretized domain using select families of basis functions
elements.2211.03241_53ab3c01ca6f21d8435d865f2cc06: A significant part of PDE solver technology involves solving PDEs on complex, irregular domains (for instance, flow across aerofoils in aeronautics or patient-specific organ geometries in medical diagnostics)
elements.2211.03241_e1a25ff92c4b935d946d3af896e91: This is a major challenge, as articulated in the NASA CFD 2030
elements.2211.03241_b7711096baceb8f3f48bbaacb3867: Mesh generation and adaptivity continue to be significant bottlenecks...
elements.2211.03241_09cf6b2a8032703778925360b583f: In particular, capturing the complex geometry, as well as rigorously accounting for the non-trivial boundary conditions on these complex geometries, has driven careers in mesh generation and PDE solver technology
elements.2211.03241_a64a747a7f77eef4c73ab2441b0c2: Motivated by these challenges, this paper addresses the following problem,
elements.2211.03241_db61846bbf381be4f93912cb44440: Can we design a neural PDE solver that can produce field solutions across arbitrary geometries?
elements.2211.03241_ac68c2178d52415857857f37a8e60: We do so by utilizing an analytical approach developed in the computational mechanics community
elements.2211.03241_c5d0238d2956fdd7b059ac8f6c94f: In such approaches, the irregular geometry is `immersed' in a regular grid, thus allowing standard meshes to model irregular geometries
elements.2211.03241_6bef1d03d38916e068e3ba9e51732: We extend this powerful approach to neural PDE solvers, which enables the creation of PDE solvers that can produce field solutions for a distribution of irregular geometries
elements.2211.03241_ebe1668fa8b60868acbaa22e66a8e: We show that such an approach also allows the natural incorporation of different boundary conditions over complex geometries; as a side benefit, our approach also allows us to compute
elements.2211.03241_ea1619d072b11065f6e828ddbd050: error estimates using a combination of techniques from neural net generalization and finite element analysis.
elements.2211.03241_a9799ef2b3935890606ea50bc3a63: Since neural networks are powerful nonlinear function approximators, there has been a growing interest in using neural networks to solve PDEs
elements.2211.03241_3d5a5e03d2c9797711ebb4b0f262c: \citep{raissi2019physics,kharazmi2019variational, sirignano2018dgm,yang2018physics, pang2019fpinns, karumuri2020simulator, han2018solving, michoski2019solving, samaniego2020energy, ramabathiran2021spinn, lu2019deeponet,botelho2020deep,balu2021distributed,wandel2021spline}
elements.2211.03241_dbdb3e26f7e5fcd80198f7adf7212: Unlike numerical methods, many of these methods do not require a mesh
elements.2211.03241_3197743e91260ae4dff197cfa0b15: But a common challenge most neural PDE solvers face is the efficient imposition of boundary conditions, especially on non-cartesian boundaries
elements.2211.03241_49cdf724416806971a9f8942c1bbd: Furthermore, among collocation-based neural solvers, the satisfaction of certain regularity conditions becomes non-trivial to impose
elements.2211.03241_917266f2940dcb81d5f5ad1a2564c: Classical numerical methods such as finite difference (FDM) or finite element methods (FEM) generally employ a grid or mesh to discretize the domain geometry and function space.
elements.2211.03241_9bb1b256a84795f0b7626d28cbabd: Solving PDEs defined on complex geometries requires a mesh to be prepared before the analysis
elements.2211.03241_5e1bfc6b61faebeca9d718943e78a: This step, commonly known as the
elements.2211.03241_838032d868073df94c01c8d3a880c: step, is non-trivial and often expensive.
elements.2211.03241_f05605073937b8e925370d3fdf7e0: are one way to overcome this challenge
elements.2211.03241_dd971ba1d3b7196a6f50551e739f6: The computational grid is simplified in immersed methods by considering a rectilinear axis-aligned grid that encloses the irregular geometry (within which we seek a PDE solution)
elements.2211.03241_8ce52fe7ea8e6f3d9e076b2b52ad5: Thus, a part of the background mesh forms the actual computational mesh; the rest of the background mesh is considered exterior, and thus not used in the computation of the PDE solution
elements.2211.03241_aa7144cfed011be2df09196523215: In this work, we combine the generalization capability of deep neural networks to solve PDEs defined on irregularly-shaped domains using ideas from immersed finite element methods
elements.2211.03241_2304eaede4eafaae5c6cfb19666e6: In recent years, immersed methods have been favored for massive parallel implementations since all computations are performed on a regular grid
elements.2211.03241_d541c68882fb8e72f5d09bd67f66c: This fact translates to tensor-based operations in convolutional neural networks, which otherwise are unsuitable for dealing with complex geometrical contours
elements.2211.03241_8a0a0413a9f94dbf4a655305b5d8b: A key ingredient is the careful design of the loss function, along with a mechanism to determine the interior/exterior (in-out) of the computational domain
elements.2211.03241_9d6bb41d089c1eac9c68d4483216c: Our main contributions are as follows:
elements.2211.03241_7d1b694ca12f25602b7bac1dd5e7a: We present a parametric PDE-based loss function that learns robust and watertight boundary conditions imposed by complex geometries
elements.2211.03241_34a186570fbce4b76fe9b88e04c5b: Using this loss function, we train a deep neural network
elements.2211.03241_27073f7c3b90f73e4f51cc6ed9ae9: that uses the geometric information as input to predict a field solution that satisfies the governing PDE over the arbitrary domain
elements.2211.03241_fcee45c367c2f04f559c045d25fec: We show that a single trained IBN can produce solutions to a PDE across a distribution of arbitrary shapes.
elements.2211.03241_89f4fb7103cde5894a0f67ca765ec: We provide analysis of convergence and generalization error bounds of the proposed PDE-based loss function with the immersed approach.
elements.2211.03241_f4b3be0652629fc5277c009799a8b: Finally, we use this parametric PDE-based loss function to learn solutions of PDEs over irregular geometries
elements.2211.03241_f66d05f0a82c12b9397be96c8ce1e: We illustrate the approach on two PDEs
elements.2211.03241_d38528f44f6e5a1dfb49681cf940f: and a host of irregular geometries in 2D and 3D
elements.2211.03241_3c76b3076d4070f1dfce3fbb8e179: IBN opens up fast design exploration and topology optimization for various societally critical applications such as shape design for energy harvesters, and aerodynamic design of vehicles.

elements.2211.03241_1e52476fc8855275f8b2d6c58b881: A key novelty of our method lies in formulating an appropriate PDE loss function for irregular geometries and their associated numerics

elements.2211.03241_5cdc053999d88bdd94bf7925deba9: In this section, we provide results from our proposed immersed neural approach
elements.2211.03241_86f99e27d21726ad6320ddc529715: We highlight single instance field solutions for Poisson's and Navier-Stokes equations and the field solutions to Poisson's equation for a family of randomly generated shapes
elements.2211.03241_b120867e853697fead0f4bc49e9a7: As previously mentioned, the IBN framework can map geometry representation to the field solution of a given PDE
elements.2211.03241_e6d790550042967fecb91402f51db: While the geometry representation could be an unstructured point cloud or other structured representations such as NURBS control points, the PDE field solution is represented as a uniform grid
elements.2211.03241_6155d2c01aa22c91bfbb70c819acb: We use a single Nvidia Tesla P40 GPU in all the experiments shown below
elements.2211.03241_9e36cfab2b0beb7a58f3792126e1d: Each network used the Adam optimizer with a learning rate of 3e-4
elements.2211.03241_55a6c5d5e590b1b274b41ba55ecfd: , we have two approaches for obtaining the occupancy information(
elements.2211.03241_d7bf3662b8b487e7dd25f1787c131: A comparison between both the methods is provided in the Supplement, and we only show generalized winding number-based results here.
elements.2211.03241_ee51f68c1af1edbf62c48eb3be784: For solving Poisson's Equation in 2D, we first generate a large geometry data (a family of NURBS curves sampled randomly)
elements.2211.03241_08485dc921d18a3e2b79b1285b973: We ensure that the shapes are smooth and do not have any discontinuities and self-intersections
elements.2211.03241_4682e448b5f9847c3d96f0f27ab67: Once the shapes are generated, we obtain point clouds composed of 1,000 points, and all field solutions were represented using a
elements.2211.03241_4d379c81ef39e6b3a7d5762b35eed: Our neural network to map the point cloud to the image domain was composed of 6 MLP layers followed by 8 layers of convolution and transpose convolution operations
elements.2211.03241_77db46a71f31ca8b751c179bd36a5: Here, we choose simple MLP layers, but more sophisticated architectures such as DGCNNs could also be used.

elements.2211.03241_17ae8ead526be2c2dbdd5608183c5: to numerical solution obtained using traditional approaches such as
elements.2211.03241_42d71dcf9b26d700b7488fc499c0b: Similarly, we show these comparisons for PINNs as well
elements.2211.03241_71a3da17312742768abd9c6fed04b: Our approach is consistently more accurate than PINNs in predicting the field solutions
elements.2211.03241_b655665999dacdc4757983950680a: Also, the training time for PINNs is much higher than the training time for
elements.2211.03241_d4fa0a0ede6f42e2acec7d1d19f42: Since PINNs can deal with only one geometry at a time, we show similar training behavior, but our approach can generalize to more than one geometry.
elements.2211.03241_884b867506f62094794fc6e9bb53c: One of the major limitations is that compared to other neural PDE solvers, our proposed approach is more memory intensive while being better and faster than them
elements.2211.03241_ae77fa061ba9009a64c47b508a336: Further, the two occupancy information calculation approaches have a trade-off
elements.2211.03241_96e973724a105628e64989def6352: While the winding number-based approach is easier to calculate and faster, they are not robust to noise and require huge memory resources to perform the computation
elements.2211.03241_ed1f397dc4841252b571546dae3d3: Similarly, the Eikonal equation-based approach is more robust to noise in the geometry representation and has a smaller memory footprint, but suffers from a long time to compute the SDF accurately and causes initial stability issues.
elements.2211.03241_9cc22ae82c0a6120f0852bd6de704: We have developed a neural PDE solver that can handle irregularly shaped domains by building on well-established finite element and immersed boundary methods
elements.2211.03241_f7be61539b8f42a41b20459ad885c: Our neural PDE solver, coined IBN, demonstrates the ability to predict field solutions for irregular boundaries immersed in the target domain
elements.2211.03241_4ed13d891942ff3ea137fa870c5f1: We highlight two specific PDE cases, Poisson and Navier-Stokes, which show promising results
elements.2211.03241_dbba50a4ec88e653aedec39c61c19: Alongside the empirical results, we have included theoretical results for the error bounds of the optimization process of our finite element-based loss function
elements.2211.03241_fd44c84943f90395882b8df9af750: IBN opens up fast design exploration and topology optimization for various societally critical applications such as room ventilation for reduced disease risk, shape design for energy harvesters, and aerodynamic design of vehicles.

elements.2211.03241_7a55c9246a9372b4f89b12839c7ef: mainly comprises 2D and 3D transpose convolution operations
elements.2211.03241_cce1352637cb6df7983b0941fe484: The dimensionality of the transpose convolution operation will match the dimensionality of the domain we are solving for
elements.2211.03241_7512b0a2947ab64d0d542817e3ed0: We use transpose convolutions as a trainable up-sampling scheme
elements.2211.03241_fb642aaa12fb034999d8c9a73f78a: This is favored compared to deterministic methods such as interpolation-based upsampling methods or unpooling operations due to the added learning capacity transpose convolutions offer
elements.2211.03241_05a364f5522c538658a8687ab620d: The kernel size of the transpose convolution operation is initialized to encapsulate information from a neighborhood of NURBS control points.
elements.2211.03241_7ac8f6b694fa1edbd7c9d221bf025: We can accurately apply the boundary conditions to arbitrary complex domains
elements.2211.03241_b4a3bb4bd57819aaff44866d6e816: We accomplish this by learning the in-out function associated with a given boundary
elements.2211.03241_532c4487c617ab488a8fcae849447: We optimize our network to learn the in-out function using a differentiable winding numbers loss function outlined in detail below
elements.2211.03241_313efad90df300503a1d2a7d42315: The optimized in-out function approximation sets the elements inside the boundary to 1 and outside the boundary to 0
elements.2211.03241_007cb0541c3d40ed57e426e753eb5: The inside of the object also inherits the conditions at its boundary; therefore, the Dirichlet condition is applied to all the points in the background mesh assigned a positive winding number, along with the points on the object surface
elements.2211.03241_03f69fec755ddb8d4b1dce388292a: The nodes assigned zero values are understood to belong to the computational domain, thus being used for further computations
elements.2211.03241_3f831f92c7b0863258db090c2217b: We then apply this processed in-out prediction as the boundary condition to the predicted field solution using a similar

elements.2211.03241_0ab20fa71aee8f0c87610e51ed2e5: In this work we used a dataset consisting of point clouds, and the corresponding normals, which outline Non-Uniform Rational B-Splines (NURBS) curves to represent the boundaries of irregular domains
elements.2211.03241_d25f78c97c2bf6212e0f2603c9319: NURBS curves are presented by a set of control points, with each control point being described by cartesian coordinates, in this case only (
elements.2211.03241_034c04b0de8dde25ffd6e2c82acce: For this dataset, we selected points along the x-axis which were uniformly spaced from 0 to 1
elements.2211.03241_a637148168ec4e798e18f207dbff0: The corresponding coordinates along the y-axis were randomly sampled from a uniform distribution with a minimum value of 0.2 and a maximum value of 0.8
elements.2211.03241_3e312fdcd48c9a1ff4a2cd0dc1b85: To attain the point cloud on the boundary defined by the NURBS curve we utilized NURBS-Python
elements.2211.03241_06eec51c42fd8367b59097f2783a4: NURBS-Python not only provides a point cloud on the boundary of the NURBS curve, but also the normals, unique vectors for each point in the point cloud pointing in the orthogonal direction with respect to the boundary
elements.2211.03241_95567105d6032cfdc73178e28502e: Additionally, the area for each point is required for the calculation of the winding number
elements.2211.03241_c3c549852c76082ba496e16a810bb: In this work we assume each point has a uniform area, which we maintain for each irregular boundary in the entire dataset.
elements.2211.03241_3939a9db32def57fcfb2baf09b26d: As explained in the main paper, winding number for a given point cloud
elements.2211.03241_96ca347d5d6d8b655e4b68da68b2f: In order to evaluate the winding number at all the nodal locations, we perform all the pairwise distance computations between every nodal location and every point in the pointcloud and perform a sum reduction of the pairwise distances as per the above equation

elements.2211.03241_d9418cd82b4b3f6e12fd16c03caea: During experimentation, we demonstrated two different methods of generating masks to impose the boundary conditions on our predicted field solution during the Finite Element loss computation
elements.2211.03241_9d0974316acec64540106948542ed: The first was with a differentiable winding number method
elements.2211.03241_270e25293ef4d20c01a2293dce8c9: The second leverages the Finite Element framework to solve the Eikonal equation
elements.2211.03241_d57f3084ce2b585ca6068bdc9cf74: The field solution to the Eikonal equation is a signed distance field
elements.2211.03241_27b4d583cbddbb2e06a15f930468d: Once a signed distance field is obtained for the irregular boundary, we use a differentiable conditional function to create an accurate binary mask from the signed distance field.
